Risk Management Plan Executive Summary for the SI Group Inc. Tennessee Operations
 
SI Group, Inc. is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is reinforced by compliance with the OSHA PSM requirements through a comprehensive accidental release prevention program in place that covers design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process at our facility.      

SI Group Inc. is highly committed to decrease the likelihood that a release will occur, but unforeseeably if such a release does occur, our highly trained emergency response personnel in coordination with the Cocke County Emergency Management Agency will contol and mitigate the effects of the release.  At SI Group Inc., control is implemented by applying  six layers of protection.  

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies.
The first layer of protection is comprised of our employees who are highly trained to utilize the distributive control system to safely operate the process.  The second line of defense is implementation of our Mechanical Integrity Program which complies with the OSHA PSM rules and ensures integrity and preventative maintenance on the equipment.  Thirdly, Hazard Reviews through HAZOP Process Hazard Analysis have been conducted by examining all process procedures and equipment. The process controls and devices such as relief control valves and flares, make up the fourth layer of protection.  Backing up the controls is the monitoring system, which includes continual data readout by operators in the control room. A sixth layer of protection is provided by our Emergency Response team, which has at its disposal equipment sufficient to control a release. 
The Cocke County Fire Department is familiar with our facilty and can provide prompt backup.     

2. The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled.
Our facility's primary activities encompasses organic chemi

cal synthesis. The RMP regulated chemical at our facility is 2-Methylpropene (CAS 115-11-7). This chemical is a byproduct of the chemical production process and is more commonly called isobutylene.

3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The facility is operated to comply with OSHA PSM 29 CFR 1910.119, which includes designs and mechanical integrity based on ASME standards. The operating procedures specifically address release prevention of the substance according to OSHA PSM. The site is also subject to control requirements under the EPA Title V Air Permit Program. The 2-Methylpropene storage and transfer facilities are designed according to NFPA 58 (Liquified Petroleum Gas Code). Pressure vessels are designed and tested according to State of Tennessee regulations on boilers and pressure vessels. 

A. Process Safety Information.
SI Group Inc. maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating safety information, operating parameters, and equipment designs.

B. Process Hazard Analysis
SI Group Inc. has conducted and will revalidate as needed, comprehensive studies to ensure hazards are identified and controlled. The methodology used to carry out the analyses are HAZOP and what if checklists. In addition, based on the PHA findings, further evaluations are conducted using a Layer Of Protection Analysis (LOPA)to determine if additional controls are needed per a Safety Instrumented System (SIS) The methods are based on the IEC 61511 Functional safety -Safety instrumented systems for the process industry 2003-01. Any findings are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
The procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  Consequences of deviation and emergency procedures are included.

Training
The SI Group Inc. emergency response personnel are organized in

to teams with an Incident Commander per each shift. The personnel are all trained as 24 hours Hazmat Technicians Level.  In addition, the team members are trained as a Fire Brigade with at least 20 additional hours of initial training.  Refresher fire brigade and hazmat training  according to OSHA HAZWOPER is conducted each year.

Mechanical Integrity
SI Group Inc. conducted detailed pre-startup mechanical integrity and continues to carry out highly documented maintenance checks on such equipment as pressure vessels, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. 

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place at SI Group Inc. to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. All employees are trained and participate in the Management of Change system.

Pre-startup 
Before startup of the process or changes in the process, formal safety reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing the equipment in operation.

Compliance Audits
SI Group Inc. conducts audits to determine that the provisions under PSM and RMP are implemented. These audits will be repeated at least every three years. SI Group' application for the Tennessee OSHA (TOSHA) Volunteer Star (VPP) program has been accepted and based on the successful on-site TOSHA evaluation completed on May 9, 2013, TOSHA  will recommend to the Commissioner of the Tennessee Department of Labor and Workforce Development that SI Group - Tennessee Operations be awarded Tennessee STAR VPP status.

Employee Participation
Employees participated in the PHA and pre-startup safety reviews as well as contibuted to modifying the design and procedures for the safest operation. Employees are encouraged to participate per team meetings and safety meetings.  Annually a letter is distributed asking for employee's continued input.

Contractors
A detailed written program for approving, hi

ring, orienting, and evaluating contractors on the potential hazards in the facility is implemented at the SI Group Inc. plant. In the orientation contractors are trained in their role in emergencies.

4. Five-year Accident History

The SI Group Inc. plant startedup in August 2005. There have been no emergency releases.


5. Emergency Response Plan

The emergency response plan is written in the format of the EPA's One Plan or Integrated Contingency Plan. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including rescue and follow up first aid or medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies, and the public. Included are specific procedures for the RMP regulated substance, 2-Methylpropene. The emergency equipment is regularly inspected and tested.

The Cocke County Emergency Management Agency Director and the Cocke County Fire Chief has been provided a copy of the plan and is familiar with the plant site. The Cocke County Fire Chief and the State Fire Marshall has also reviewed the NFPA 58 Fire Safety Analysis for storage of the 2-Methylpropene.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

An improvement to the fire protection system by adding additional sprinkler heads to provide cooling water for vertical steel columns in the process building has been completed.
